resource.chars:
The Govt. School of Mines, Jermyn St
July 18. 1856
Mr Raineys observations upon pigs infested 
with the Cysticercus cellulosae, appear to 
establish the following facts 
1. The cellular Tissue contains bodies resembling 
the vesicle of the Cysticercus in structure and 
presenting every gradation from the possession of a more or 
less completely developed head with nucleus 
and hooks to a condition in which these 
appendages are entirely absent. These bodies 
are contained in cysts and are not less than 1/10’ to 1/20’ in diameter.
2. Within the sarcolemma of the primitive 
Muscular fascicules “vermiform” bodies are 
contained some of which are not more than 
1/150th of an inch in length - They have 
a distinct membranous wall which in the 
larger forms is level with short perpendicular 
fibres and they contain masses of peculiar 
reniform corpuscles -
3. Aggregations of reniform corpuscles of a similar 
character but without any  investing membrane 
lie in the substance of the muscular fasciculi 
4. Irregular corpuscles are found loosely scattered 
in the substance of the muscles in conjunction 
with the earliest forms of Cysticercus and in such
cases only (p27)
5. The capillaries are, in many cases where Cysticerci 
abound, altered and their ... more or less 
blocked up with minute molecules
